commentBody: One across sums up my feelings about this one: MEH. ü´§

Pretty straightforward, solved in essentially one pass, nothing too challenging here.  Couldn‚Äôt be bothered to figure out the theme.  Seemed like a hard Tuesday in difficulty‚Ä¶. Solved in just over half my average Sunday time‚Ä¶
My fastest Sunday this year!

Knot too hard.

-  Tom
This puzzle is like my favourite Sunday dinner, pot roast. Not difficult to do,  but oh so comforting and delicious.

I could spin a yarn about crochet, but it'd be a bait-and-stitch.

(It's still threader than nothing.)

My personal preference for a Sunday crossword is a theme (a) that I need to use to solve the puzzle or (b) that has me laughing while solving, or both. The constructor found some words that could be "knotted." I appreciate that, but this was neither (a) or (b) for me.

YMMV.

Nice one! 79A had me scratching my head until I read Caitlin‚Äôs comments. The theme helped me find the error I had made with a Y at the crossing of 76D and 92A.  I could have got it from the nonsense I had for 92A but it was fun to let the theme guide me.

A satisfying aha moment when I realized how ALL TIED UP related to the circled letters.

Fabulous clue for NINE LIVES, ‚ÄúThe stuff of Persian myths‚Äù and the clue for MIMI, ‚ÄúOpera character whose name might be heard in an opera singer's warm-up‚Äù gave me a good chuckle. 

I love that my other favorite pastime, CROSS STITCH, is one of the theme entries along with STRING and THREAD. For me that made the puzzle sew much fun!

Hear Ye! This is the last announcement for nominations for Puzzle of the Year. Please REPLY to this message with any of your picks from 2024 in the four categories:
M-W
Thursdays
Fri-Sat 
Sundays
Nomination deadline is midnight Sunday the 12th. After which we (Eric Hougland, Cat Lady Margaret and I) will tally and give you a list of the nominations and instructions on voting, which will be in two rounds. All we need is the DATE of the puzzle, the NAME(S) of the constructor(s), and -- optional -- the reasons why it merits a nomination for the best of the year.

By the way, editors, Wordplay columnists, and anyone who can get on to this thread -- are all welcome to nominate & to vote.

The theme made me smile when I figured it out, and while I probably didn‚Äôt need it to complete the puzzle, it sped up the SE corner by helping me complete QUEEN OF CARNIVAL. I had been looking for a trick that give me enough room for QUEEN OF BOURBON ST or QUEEN OF MARDI GRAS earlier, and when no tricks were to be had, figured I would need to come back with the crossings. 

For me, a nice, pleasant, gentle Sunday puzzle, after a long and tiring day!

I don‚Äôt mind what words get used in a puzzle, truly.
But I couldn‚Äôt help registering my feelings about one of today‚Äôs entries:

MEH, you again? Source of so much ANGST.
EYEROLL.  A LESION on our civic life. Would rather have COOTIES. Or THANOS. Or NIXON.  Try your ABUSES at the other end of a SPACE TELESCOPE, why don‚Äôt you.
Sorry my SENTIMENTS are so CATTISH - that‚Äôs just how it is.
I liked it! My only problem is that one of my answers is supposedly wrong, but I can't see where the error is. It's where cross stitch crosses q tip - the T is marked in red. Is this actually wrong?

This puzzle threaded nicely for me and practically sew-lved itself. 

There were many names I didn't know, for which I needed the crosses.
But intertwined with that, there were a lot of gems which I enjoyed. 

Thank you, Mr. Martinovic!

I solved this one steadily while watching football playoffs, and didn‚Äôt figure out the theme.  Other than performing an EYEROLL  at CATTISH and DIYER (would an American League baseball player who is handy around the house be an alerdiyer?), I had no strong feelings about this one.

Definitely knot going to break any records for number of comments‚Ä¶knot that there‚Äôs anything wrong with that.

Thanks for the puzzle!
I solved this one very quickly compared to my usual Sunday efforts.
I solved this puzzle very quickly even though I didn't get the gimmick until I read the blog.

Yeah okay.  Didn't get the theme while solving (it wasn't needed).  I figured it was going to turn out to be either delightfully clever or really meh.

It was really meh.  But thanks to the column for explaining.   I guess this is one of those things that seemed a lot more interesting in the constructor's head?

Happy for anyone who enjoyed it though, truly....

Other than that it was a decent, fast Sunday.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Next.
Yay no hint solve! Yesterday‚Äôs needed every hint I could get. The theme definitely helped me out. The north part was somehow the toughest for me. Solved it in about average time. Nice one!
I was truly thinking about cancelling my subscription (feeling that I was simply too old). The last three days have been great, challenging puzzles. Thankful!

That one ticked along steadily until I ran aground in the region of 74A, 81A, 87A, 92A, with two unknown singers and some sort of cartoon fish crossing something to do with video games, and all thrown sideways by my conviction that 74A was SAYSyes.
Only rescued from lookups by the theme cells, which broke PLAYABLE for me, even though I couldn't even understand that word for a minute or so. (I got PLAYA wedged in my head.) A couple of plausible singer/fish names then materialized with good crosses, while I tried to ignore the incomprehensible OLEMISS in my peripheral vision, and was astonished to get the happy tune with no revisions.

I liked the theme! Took me a while to get PLAYABLE for online gaming character, had QUEEN OF Mardigra(s) before CARNIVAL and 
didn‚Äôt cheat as much. Liked the central wordplay the best of STRING AND THREAD.
Loved 79A---because I work there :)  Hotty Toddy!

My only nit was cluing of ASANA at 7D as  'Sitting meditation pose'.   ASANA is general term which includes many non-sitting yoga poses (lying down, standing, and many positions which are neither of these), so simply  'Meditation pose' would have been an adequate and less misleading clue.  

Specifying  'Sitting' suggested one well known sitting pose 'lotus'  (A pose that involves literally tying ones legs in a knot!).

Fun puzzle that chugged along nicely. Very few lookups (unusual for me) as the crosses filled in lots of the letters. 

The theme didn't jump out at me until I'd finished but nay matter, it worked out in the end. PURIST had me stuck for a while, I had PEDANT initially. Similarly, CATLIKE for CATTISH, TRIPSUP for SLIPSUP and SODA for RYES.

Special mention to PITCREW, VOWS and TUNE for the excellent wordplay in their clues. 

It's 3.50am in London and way past my bedtime. üò¥

I solved this fairly quickly without understanding the significance of the circled letters. I was slowed down a bit by 9D, where I inexplicably had GROWTH LIneS at first (which made me wonder if MUST-LEADS were part of the trick).

It turned out there wasn‚Äôt much of a trick. Nor was there anything that resembled a challenge.
Being somewhat emoji illiterate today I learned that is the EYEROLL emoji. Loved the kittens photo, Caitlin. And let's hear it for DENIECE Williams. https://youtu.be/lO3mcWb2nTk?si=iF-9nBukm2d2rhXk
I was in the zone.  Please don‚Äôt tell gad about it being too easy.  I got a personal record today, and I don‚Äôt need to question whether or not I earned it.

This is obnoxiously pedantic, but we all love trivia so I hope to be forgiven. 35A is correct for Russia, but Bulgaria had a tsar until 1946. The last Tsar of the Bulgarians, Simeon II, was deposed while still a child, but is still alive and even served as prime minister for a time.
Puzzle is a put on - just don knot(t)s.
I totally missed the theme in the rush to solve.  I had to read the column to find out what it was.
My grandma had that sewing machine and I used it. Amazing trip down memory lane  :)

I thought it wasn‚Äôt possible. But here I am. Sitting here. With the gold star on my screen. I just did a Sunday puzzle without any lookups, hints, help, or even coming to the column. In 31 minutes. AND I guessed the theme all on my own :)

I do apologize for gloating but I‚Äôm gonna have to pat myself on the back for this one, do a little tooting of my own horn. I‚Äôm submitting a screenshot of this in lieu of my homework assignments this week. I feel a thrill, a rush, a newfound vigor. While this was no Thursday/ Friday/ Saturday, soon no puzzle will be safe from me >:) This is merely the beginning. 

Let this be a beacon of hope to all you crossword newbies out there, young and old, digital or paper users: the day WILL come. Whether it be Monday or Thursday or Saturday or Sunday, your first 100% no help grid awaits

Now to retreat back into my corner of crossword obscurity as I continue to thrash through the archives. Have a lovely day, all :)

What an enjoyably easy Sunday puzzle! I really like my Sundays like today's: very few lookups needed, a theme that does not make the puzzle clue worse. There are few things worse in griddom than a tough, overly complex Sunday that takes an hour of pain to solve (or fail to solve!)

Most of my observations today had to do with units:

I only know PSI as a tire pressure unit because one of our cars is American. BTU I learned doing NYT puzzles. Also, why was there no abbr. indication in the clue for AMP? I know it's ok to skip that for an AMP in a sound system, but as a unit? Over here AMPere (amper in Polish) is never shortened. But then again, us Poles shorten words very rarely compared to Americans.

I thought it was a very pleasant Sunday morning puzzle. 

Thanks.
Now that I‚Äôm using the timer I can‚Äôt be starting these  Sunday puzzles so late in the evening. Taking 1:02:33 to finish put me way past my bedtime!

Just did the controversial Tuesday and was too late to comment on that one. But wanted to say: it was a fine puzzle but a rubbish Tuesday. The difference between Friday and Tuesday is not even necessarily difficulty but the type of clueing one expects. Editors are to blame, as it could easily have been nudged up to an enjoyable Friday.

One could say more, but typing on a phone is painful, metaphorically speaking.

Now to do the Sunday. ; )
This was fun, clarity gradually emerging from confusion. Thanks!
Weak again. And are we giving up on flagging abbrs ?
Great puzzle. One question - the answer to 26A is beyond me.

CALLIT reminded me of No Country for Old Men, and the Cormac McCarthy's arch villian Anton Chigur. One guy's lucky day: https://youtu.be/3B_rRmkbA9I If you're not squeamish all the scenes: https://youtu.be/Ra1TzANpoGk Is he in the Corac

I often surmise that our initial guesses can reveal a lot about ourselves.  In my own experience, yup.  My answer to 1D (common first word) was MINE.  This will not surprise my husband.  It reminds me of the story about CG Jung, where he had a patient of many years who one day said to him, "Dr. Jung, I fooled you!!  I made up all those dreams!" and Jung responded, "yes, but YOU made them up."

This was a strange one for me‚Ä¶ so many answers that didn‚Äôt seem quite right, yet fit and (mostly) turned out to be correct. So while I should feel good about it, I never felt I had the upper hand. Or the lower hand. Or any hand. And I didn‚Äôt get the theme, even after solving. MEH. It‚Äôs probably just me.

Nice puzzle, really enjoyed it! 

You may see a few say they finished the puzzle without bothering to solve for the theme (no problem) but then note they didn't find it challenging enough (ahem....)

I respectfully submit that the puzzle isn't fully 'finished' until one has solved for the theme. In the case of this puzzle, as Caitlin comments, the theme was unlikely to help solve any specific clues. Solving for the theme is itself the final clue. 

Hmm.. all answers filled in correctly, now what is the significance of the circled letters, how do these relate to the relevant clues, and relate back to the puzzle title? Solving for that was one thing that made this puzzle fun. If a solver chooses not to complete the puzzle, that's up to them, but they shouldn't then be complaining that the puzzle wasn't challenging enough.

I'm a tad surprised, or maybe annoyed, that the comments on many recent puzzles have seemed like whines about their difficulty, or the obscurity of some of the references.  And then when one like this is published - so simple and uninspiring that I end up focusing on time-to-solve, rather than enjoying the experience, people love it. I'll take hard, or creative, any day.

I don't think we're in Kansas anymore. Where was I? Oh yeah - a tough one for me and of course had to cheat some to get through it. And... must confess that I never really caught on to the theme while I was solving. Apparently I'm not alone in that. No big deal. And... a somewhat appropriate puzzle find today. A Thursday from November 17, 2011 by Patrick Merrell. This one was in the clues. Here are some clue/answer examples, starting with the 'reveal': "Stronger title" for this puzzle LETTERSORTING And some other theme clues and answers: "Duplex mail" ALLMIXEDUP "Roof detour" OUTOFORDER "Rear garden" REARRANGED "Mad manager" ANAGRAMMED Had to furrow my brow before it all finally dawned on me. And then my jaw dropped. That was just... truly amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/17/2011&g=26&d=A I'm done. ...

"Today's theme?  Filamentary, my dear Watson!"






Et tu, emu.
Easy, mostly enjoyable puzzle - thanks! - but I have to read about Elon in the news; do i really need to see him in my puzzle too?

My first Sunday that I finished under an hour and I only had to correct one thing ‚Äî what I thought was ANKLET for AMULET after seeing the crosses!!

As a newer solver (less than a year) I get intrigued reading the comments. Some make me chuckle, some I respond to, but recently many have made me feel not part of the typical ‚Äúsolving crowd.‚Äù A history of my comments might hint towards that. A solve I felt like was at a great level for me for, say, a Tuesday, or today‚Äôs Sunday becomes invalidated when seeing complaints about what ‚Äúday‚Äù a certain difficulty is supposed to be on or how ‚Äúeasy‚Äù something is.

I get it for all the people who are used to a routine where a certain level of candor or wordplay is expected, but a big part of me remembers that trivia and wording change all the time with different constructors and editors: the more I play, the more this will get easier for me as I figure out patterns, like how this game really endorses OREOS. But also, the more I play, the older and more experienced I‚Äôll get about certain topics that the NYT crossword may or may not discuss or phrases outside of my repertoire.

So what if you miss a few, or if a day just doesn‚Äôt mesh with your abilities, when it finally instilled confidence to newer people like me?
Another puzzle that I didn't have much trouble filling in but had no clue what the theme was until after it was finished. It was okay.
Really enjoyed this one. Only a few obscure trivia to look up. Lots to actually solve.
really enjoyed this one, and loved the theme clues! a little crunchy but doable with little to no lookups, and a satisfying finish.

I liked that the pairs of words in each theme answer turn on a single letter. It reminded me of that moment in gift wrapping, where I start to tie a ribbon into a knot, and ask someone to press their finger onto what I‚Äôve tied so I can finish it. That single letter uniting the two words in each theme answer evoked that feeling.

That brought a "Huh!" and a "Hah!" 

I also got a kick out of CATTISH, a strange, funny, and likable word to me, just like yesterday‚Äôs PANTSED.

Plus, joy came as well from a pair of original clues ‚Äì [Some professions] for VOWS, and [Opera character whose name might be heard in an opera singer‚Äôs warmup] for MIMI.

Not to mention having an area in the grid that refused to buckle, where I had to solve around it, approach it from a different direction to finally conquer it.  My brain loves this kind of work.

And, finally, this random theme about tying knots and what they may be tied with.  That is so out of the box!  Who thinks of that?  I love running into things like that.

So, your creation took me to a happy place, Jeffrey. Thank you for all the labor you put into this.  You brightened my day!
Okay, as for the far-fetched and convoluted theme I say [SPOILER ALERT!!!] "Meh," but as for the puzzle overall, quite good, and perfect for a Sunday.
It's always such a pleasure when somehow you find yourself on the same wavelength as the constructor.  A real pleasure to work on this one; thanks!

Overall this puzzle is just 1 Across.  Close to PB without the theme registering until I got here.

I am sure there is significant lead time in selecting these, but they should have reconsidered the clue for 52A in such proximity to 53A given the tragic news out of the state with 46D this week.

Fun puzzle. Tumbled the theme early but didn‚Äôt really use it. Not upset that it was a breeze to solve (probably my second-fastest Sunday) but I confess I do look forward to sinking into the Sunday puzzle like a warm bath ‚Äî and this was more of a quick shower. Still, clever even if it didn‚Äôt (ahem) tie me in knots.

Great puzzle! FWIW, LOVE TO makes sooooo much more sense than NO VETO. Got a little tied up on that one, and I also wondered what the English had against currency.

Happy Sunday!

I‚Äôve spied really hard, but still can‚Äôt find all the hidden ‚Äúwires‚Äù.
They must be tuned to a *very* high see.

No Jello, but a lot of little words in this light salad.
(and also, the less said about that Paul clue, the better)

I was able to solve 90% of the clues without looking up or revealing - a record for me. There was a lot of doubling back and back to check crossers and a bit of guessing.
I forgot what AARP was, though it's been used before. I think of goad as more provoking, badgering, than to URGE ON. 
I couldn't think of another way to say no thanks, and where does the word COOTIES come from? I think the equivalent might be "the lurgy" or lurgies, not sure. 
Altoids - sounds strange to me, too like adenoids.
Enjoyable.

All right, now‚Ä¶

*This* one has *got* to make people happy.
I mean, what‚Äôs not to love?

A theme that doesn‚Äôt get you stuck,
just beautifully unfolds as you fill in the
*perfectly* Wednesday-ish difficulty 
on a Sunday grid.

Amirite?
I‚Äôm right.

Solid, relaxing Sunday.

Go Bills!

Terrific puzzle. Completely satisfying and with many clues that brought a smile to my face when I figured out the wordplay.
I was able to solve with no lookups even of the Names   I'd never heard of. That's not really a brag, (I often and without shame look up names if I'm stuck) but a compliment on the construction which allowed for me to compete it based on general knowledge.
Congratulations to the constructor.

Fortunately I reviewed my entire grid before filling my final square, or I would have lost another (short) streak. Apparently the Saxons were never at odds with the Melts. Changed SUREMAN to SURECAN and *then* filled in the A that I had reserved for last in the NE corner. Happy music, and just over 30 minutes.

An impressive construction, especially so the triple of NOSETOTAIL, GROWTHRING, SENTIMENTS all nicely tied in---see what I did there---with the best of the three thematic "knots".

Liked "Oxford institution, familiarly" for OLEMISS. More of a MEH for CATTISH. Didn't actually find the theme that interesting, but there were *a lot* of thematic elements in the grid, and I appreciate the skill needed to create a puzzle like this one. The left-right symmetry was visually pleasant as well.
Finished in less than half my average time. I‚Äôd prefer a more difficult puzzle, but sometimes it‚Äôs fun to race the clock.
I very much enjoyed this puzzle but I never did figure out the trick. I was trying to mix up the designated letters a bit too much, I think.  Another ‚Äútrick‚Äù to stash away for future reference!
Unusually quick solve.  That's okay sometimes.

Remember, the Sunday puzzle isn't supposed to be super-hard Wednesday-level is the goal.

I found this was fun. The one thing that held me up was when I thought it was a peculiar coincidence to have two answers starting with DD. I should have realized that MISS was OLE, not OLd.

Still beat my average handily.

Thanks!

An odd solve for me. While my time end up at around 40 percent faster than my average, I ended doing it bottom to top (tail to nose?). I was initially stymied in the NW so kept looking at random clues until I worked my way down to the first clue I read that I was certain about‚Ä¶115D, ‚ÄúPart of a Latin trio,‚Äù which at three letters could only be AMO, taking me back to my 13-year+-old self, starting Latin I almost 60 years ago. From then, working the SE and back up, it went quickly. While I didn‚Äôt need the theme to help solve it, when I went back after I got the star and the tune of triumph and figured out what the theme was, I found it delightful. Quite a few wonderful clues throughout‚Ä¶

I have a copy of the patent drawing for the COOTIES game, because I am special.... still 12. Pull my finger!

Fun solve with YOGAMAT as our last fill even tho one of us, not me, practices yoga every morning.

Thank you Jeffery
Enjoyable puzzle. Mimi was my favorite answer.
I tell you what, this puzzle was fun from start to finish. Good job Jeffrey! And thanks for working cooties in there! I haven't heard that one for ages.
I loved this puzzle and had a great time solving it.  I especially loved the fact that I didn't have to Google every third clue, or any of them for that matter.  Thank you!
Very nice Sunday solve, many thanks! Didn't really worry about the theme at all, but it was a nice extra little aspect.

This was clever and entertaining!  I started at the bottom, as is my wont, and shortly was staring at CARN/YABLE.  I said ALOHA to that and moved on!  Not an easy puzzle, but sussing out the different possibilities led to cold coffee and a slow solve.  

Latin trio?  EGO ERGO SUM!
Not.
PhysicsDaughter participated in MODEL UN in college and loved it--acting for a mostly-Muslim nation (during a fraught period in our nation)--and was voted an MVP (I forget the title, just the looked of joyous surprise on her face.)

For most of this puzzle I found zero gimmes!  Wow!  
It was nice to have a perfect solve.

Oh, and I found my yesterday's Comment still on the screen of my PC--I never got back there, as I usually check in on this iPad.  The "thankyou for your submission" message was there, but I'm pretty sure it never got through, and I'll never know why.    
For the record, I knew GALBA and KATE SMITH and several other "stumpers"...mostly things I figured would stump people pretty thoroughly.  

Today the Springerle dough will be rolled out and stamped.  A long process.  We had rye bread with breakfast--my other Baking Day assignment. Yum!
hands up if you had OLDER in need of a massage.

Strands Thread.  Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 

Strands #315
‚ÄúWait what?‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ

I must have been particularly fuzzy brained this morning.  Took quite some time to break into.

Flew through this one today! And love the theme :) 

Song of th day: WHATS THE USE? by the one and only Mac Miller
I loved this puzzle. It was challenging but allowed me to find the answers to the clues. The turn at the knots was a delightful trick. More, more, more of these please.

Is the 57 Across cross clue meant to imply that the answer is the medical term from hypermobile? (incorrect)

Or that hypermobile is the medical term for the answer? (correct)

I did it! Completed a Sunday crossword without needing any hints, tricky clues, or the theme revealer. For a second there, I thought I'd be ALL TIED UP, but the puzzle ended up being pleasantly PLAYABLE.
(for all you NFL fans... Go Bills!)

CATTISH?
That struck me as odd, but Caitlin says it's a delightful word.
Ok, attitude adjustment commencing . . .

Rather Friday-ish in level of vague, sideways cluing and arcane fill, IMHO.
Spots of MEH, AND ALSO, EYEROLL.
But all was PLAYABLE, I got her done.

Thanks, Jeffrey.
Nice to have Will back

I can't believe I have to point this out, but MUST READS are not recommendations. They're not suggestions. They're mandatory. Isn't it self-explanatory?

Would you say that "Thou shalt not commit adultery" and "Thou shalt not call them octopi" are "recommendations"? No, they are god's commandments! Disobey them at your own peril.

Think about it. Do you honestly believe anybody anywhere ever wanted to watch "Veronica's Closet"?!?! Of course not! But it was Must See TV.

This is fine.

A moderately enjoyable Sunday puzzle... not the trickiest theme I've come across, but it had a lot of moving parts that tied together well. I got the theme after filling in 45 across, so it helped with the rest of the solve. 

There were several clever clues, which adds to the entertainment.

I don't usually look up much on a Sunday, but the only unknowns today were easily solved by crosses. I did have one error, but it was 4A so I didn't waste too much time flyspecking. All in all, a good day.
Hidden theme-related content at 74A; SAYS I DO = "Ties the knot." That's all I've got for today.
"Big first name in American business" aw c'mon! I could have come up with a million better clues. How about "Self-proclaimed free speech absolutist"

Cute theme! Cuter picture on the blog!

I wish every puzzle could be as CATTISH as this one.
You weren‚Äôt laying in bed; you were LYING in bed.

I found this really tricky; I got the theme, worked out how to ‚Äòknot‚Äô the answers and filled about half the grid ok, then hit a wall and just couldn‚Äôt find my way through to completion. No particular clues or areas, just not on the constructor‚Äôs wave length at all I guess.
Glad so many enjoyed it. Afraid it‚Äôs going to be filed under 1A for me.
One nit; Eton isn‚Äôt a prep school. That would be ages 7 to 11. It‚Äôs what we call a Secondary (High) school for ages 13 to 18. 
Onwards to Monday.

Fun puzzle but I can‚Äôt find the third wire (3D, HIDDEN WIRES) in the crossed answers. CABLE (92A/48D) and CORD (104A/44D) make sense. But, the answers in 45A/9D (STRING/THREAD) do not contain something I would call a wire. What am I missing?
I‚Äôve read the article and still don‚Äôt understand how HIDDEN WIRES are found within? I was thinking ‚Äú wired ribbon‚Äù but that doesn‚Äôt make sense. Help?

The NE corner was my last fill, hampered by the fact I was sure 16D had to be BOLT (I don't think of footballers as 'athletes') and I've never heard of a CPA.

The funniest part was... I do my puzzles on an out of date laptop, which cannot display some emojis correctly. Although I *now* know there was an emoji as a clue for 25A, it was completely blank on my screen. When the answer became obvious, it was also very appropriate. Doh!

This unraveled quickly for me - 25 minutes faster than my average. Clever theme, clues and answers. I laughed when I filled in SAYS I DO because it ties the knot v untie the theme answers. Very clever indeed. 

Thank you, Jeffrey, for putting a smile on my face this morning. Well done on your solo Sunday!!

"I figured I may as well do something useful and let my mind wander,‚Äù said puzzle-maker Jeffrey Martinovic.

There is something unusual and beautiful in this statement that led to the creation of today's puzzle.

Loved this one! 

The theme made for a satisfying "aha!" moment about halfway through the puzzle. 

Lots of fun cluing, too - loved "Oxford Institution", "Many hit Wonder", and "stuff of Persian myths" in particular. Thanks 
Jeffrey for a bright start to a gray drizzly Sunday.

Ha! It felt easy at times but got me in the end. Tic Tacs gave me all kinds of trouble, but when I finally checked the puzzle, my issue was ‚Äúlove to.‚Äù  That does sound a lot better than ‚Äúno veto.‚Äù

Quick solve today, but really enjoyed it.

My favorite was the clue for OREO. I can imagine instructors moaning in despair when, once again, their grid can't survive without it. And once again, they have to try to come up with a new clue. This one was new to me, anyway, and took a moment.
Tuesday. On a Sunday.
Disco Stu doesn‚Äôt like disco.

I remembered to read the title and got CROSSSTICH and the first theme cross very early, which helped with the other theme crosses. My only goofs were putting SLIPUPS instead of SLIPSUP for a while and not knowing what a CRU was. Once I'd cleaned up that cluster, the rest was completed with ESE. 

Do I detect some subtle irony with ELON crossing MODELUN? I'd say his recent forays into international relations are a perfect model of what not to do.
Filled it in until I got stuck but then realized, I hadn't tried to solve the "trick" yet. Filling in ROPE/CORD and YARN/CABLE helped untie the rest of the puzzle. No lookups! Good puzzle.
Just a couple minutes over a PB. Needed that....I'm still working on the Bee. One of those days!
I'm perhaps being over sensitive, but I found the two fire themed clues/answers (for SINGED and FAINT), especially next to INRUINS in somewhat poor taste today. Sending thoughts to any solvers in LA

Since there was much talk about difficulty and solve times this week, I thought I'd look at mine. If we say Monday's solve time was "x", then the week spelled out thus:

Monday  x
Tuesday 3.28x
Wednesday 1.93x
Thursday 3.29x
Friday 2.76x
saturday 2.59x
Sunday 3.66x

So yeah, the difficulty for me didn't exactly follow the norm. But I thought it a fun week.

This was a pleasant puzzle overall, which solved rather quickly for me and very smoothly. It's rare for me to not have some tiny error in the big ole Sunday grid, but today I got the gold star right away. 

I was wondering if the theme was going to be wedding-related somehow because I first had idoS at 43 across, though VOWS still allowed me to keep my theme in mind. And I originally had SAYSyes at 74 across before changing it to SAYSIDO, which is what made me go back and change 43 across...  We also had AMO, ALOHA, and LOVETO and even SENTIMENTS to make me feel warm and fuzzy. 

Anyhow, I'll just let it be a little mini romantic theme in my head for the I Think Knot theme and what(k)not.

I particularly enjoyed the clue for NINELIVES at 107 across.

I'm grateful that puzzles typically give me a complete respite from the ANGST of current events and other life difficulties. There were a few non warm and fuzzy things in this one that jarred me out of puzzle mode into unhappily thinking of current events but I know that the puzzles are done in advance and they can't predict what will come or when so I don't fault anyone. All I can say is, to better days! üç∏

Really interesting and fun.  As usual, I solved but never understood the clue.  Only after reading wordplay and checking back and forth did the light bulb go on.  Very clever, very workable, and a classis crossword!

This was a fun theme in a pleasant puzzle to enjoy on a Sunday afternoon. No lookups, and I enjoyed watching the world‚Äôs fastest pit stop! I now know the official term for the way I talk to my cats. (PDS, not ‚Äúcattish,‚Äù LOL)
Feline=cattish........does that mean canine=dogish?  Asking for a friend.
Personal Best for a Sunday. Also had fun!
2D. Really? Ugh .... How about "North Carolina college" ?
I don't think of retail pharmacy as "in" the pharmaceutical industry, particularly.
Captain Aubrey would likely prefer more nautical terms in a puzzle featuring ropes and the like.
52a and 53a‚Äînobody over thought, ‚ÄúMaybe given the events of this week that we should edit those clues a bit?‚Äù

I really enjoyed this puzzle! I am just now finally getting a moment to say so. 

I think the thing that impressed me the most was the rather unusually large volume of 3-letter answers, and that so many of them were surprisingly fresh! (Either the words themselves or the clues to more typical answers.) I happened to enjoy all the measurement terminology, almost a mini theme: the adacent AMP, OHM, PSI and then BTU down the grid. These and other tiny words made way for some really nice long answers! 

I first tried CATlike and then found CATTISH awkward... But by the time I read Caitlin's writeup, I realized I really like it as a word. Going into regular rotation for this cat lady! ;) 

At the opposite end of the puzzle -- and puzzling -- I was happily shocked that YOGA MAT was correct on the first go! Most of this puzzle was like that for me, making for a fairly perfect Sunday solving experience, IMO. 

I will just add that the incendiary clues and answers in the middle of the grid made me mentally wince, given the horrible situation in southern California this week. Publishing schedule constraints are not something I've given much thought to 'til now, but I'd imagine there wasn't a way to modify those clues. So unfortunate, and I really feel for those solvers for whom those were too painful. May tomorrow be a better balm.
I really enjoyed today's Strands, and yesterday's too. Their winsome humor had smiling by the time I finished.
Delightful, Mr. Martinovic!

Pleasant. 
25:53 today, struggled with a bit of random fill but it never felt obnoxious
I liked the puzzle but I will admit the theme did nothing for me in terms of aiding for the solve (outside the CROSSSTICH). PITCREW stuck out to me too as a very clever clue and answer. Fun puzzle!
So glad I could ignore the "theme" (whatevs) and just solve it.

I did this puzzle by mistake. I'm actually doing May 2024 puzzles. I took a hiatus for a few months when my wife was injured. 
Anyway, I didn't get 3 down. I see cable, but none of the others are wires. I must be missing something.
Almost a year into playing these crosswords and I think I am finally improving. A fun puzzle for a newbie who is working hard to be a bit better than yesterday.

I think I have actually spotted DIYER out in the wild once or twice, unlike ‚ÄúALer.‚Äù  (But then again, I‚Äôm not a sports person.) I found it a gimme, but YMMV.

@Nick In the wild, you'll see AL as an abbreviation for American League. Back when the AL used the designated hitter, but the National League didn't, and players stayed with the same team longer, you might see some mention of American or National Leaguers as a group or a category. But I've never seen ALer (or NLer, for that matter) written that way in the wild. (Nor NFLer, NBAer, NHLer, etc.) There's no internet support for ALer or NLer; Googling ALer gives a whole bunch of other things, such as people whose last name is Aler, and NLer comes back mostly with crossword sites and other acronyms. DIYer is a real thing; Googling gives you a dictionary definition immediately and some relevant sites. This is the first one that isn't a dictionary or other language site: https://fbfs.com/learning-center/15-signs-youre-a-diyer The first Google screen shows three other non-linguistic sites as well.

@Andrzej Can't speak for North Americans, but in the UK we very rarely (almost never) say AMPere. If you were to ask anyone what the unit of current is, they would almost  always say AMP (or AMPs).

Ampere probably sounds too French for us üòâ

@Tim 

To us it sounds Polish: spelling it we skip the e at the end since we don't pronounce it, and we stress the penultimate (in this case, the first) syllable, as we usually do in Polish with Polish words. We only stress other syllables within some loanwords, like uni*wer*sytet (university) and gra*ma*tyka (grammar).

@Andrzej AMP is the everyday name of the unit. I'd bet many people--even many electricians--don't even know it's short for a longer term. There's a huge list of words in English that were once longer, some of the original versions of which are unknown to many people, and this is one of them. Bra, bike, and decaf are a few examples of shortened words that are far more common than their original versions. Decal (-comania), recap (-itulation) and pram (perambulator) are three words whose original forms are all but totally lost these days. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_English_abbreviations_made_by_shortening_words
@Andrzej Americans are always looking for shortcuts. Sometimes, they are even trying to own ones that don't belong to them. Like, the Panama Canal.

@Heg 

Americans abbreviate or shorten almost everything.
And when such a shortened word or phrase becomes as common or more common than the original word, it is accepted as a word itself, and no longer needs to be flagged as an abbreviation.

In the case of brands or corporate names, the shortened word or initials become the legal name. Most people couldn't even tell you what CVS originally stood for.

Which clues tripped you up in this puzzle?

@Andrzej I agree. We have a right to criticise - only by praise & criticism will editors get the feedback required to better perfect the product that we are paying for.

@Andrzej hey! I will accept no Subaru slander!!! ü§£

I do agree with the points you made, however.

@Lauren 
I'm not sure that criticism helps, unless you have a different meaning for the word "criticism" than I do. For people to say what they like and don't like, yes. Definitely. In addition, if someone is a puzzle constructor themselves, then it makes sense that they could offer usable, realistic suggestions. (I am not, and find I understand about as much about puzzle construction as I do about oral surgery. I can voice my opinion about my experience of it, however.) 

It's hard to see how criticizing a puzzle as "lazily constructed," for instance, would be helpful, and it's unpleasant to read. It just comes across as wanting to tear someone down rather than wanting to help them "perfect the product." All of these puzzles are created by unpaid volunteers, and I hope that doesn't change. It means we will continue to have a variety of solving experiences--we never know what to expect each day.

Much of the criticism I see here would appeal to only a part of the puzzle solving public, which prompts others to chime in to balance things out. None of us wants to lose the aspects we love, even if those aspects appear only one day a week.

@AT 

Well said!  Keep solving and commenting.  This forum is for everybody, not just the "in" crowd that always sits together at lunch (you know who you are!)

@AT

A weird thing about this forum is that you have a large (ish) group of people with *hugely* varying levels of crossword-solving skills talking about the same puzzle every day, each from their own perspective.

On top of that, there is simply no such thing as an objective/universal difficulty level for a puzzle ‚Äî every solver brings their own background to the table every day.

Point being: please don‚Äôt take it as a personal insult when people talk about how they found a given puzzle to be easier than they‚Äôd prefer (especially later in the week). You may very well find yourself thinking the exact same thing before you know it!

But regardless, there will always be *some* people in the forum who find the current day‚Äôs puzzle to be a total breeze, others who found it impossibly hard, and everything in between. And IMO they should all be able to share their own thoughts here.

(That said, I do think lots of people are quick to post critical commentary, in which they characterize a subset of clues from a puzzle as *bad*, rather than just saying that they personally struggled with them‚Ä¶and I‚Äôd love to see a lot less of that. But hey, that‚Äôs just me.)

It‚Äôs just a real head-scratcher to me how quick some commenters are to construe their own puzzlement as an indictment of puzzle/clue quality.

Saying that you found a puzzle boring, thought it had too much crosswordese or short fill, etc ‚Äî there‚Äôs no accounting for taste! But criticizing a puzzle‚Äôs clueing as bad/unfair, based entirely on how effectively the clues happened to activate associations within your own connectome?
